questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of repetitive, involuntary blinking, shrugging, and grunting for the past year. His mother states that his symptoms improve when he is physically active, while tiredness, boredom, and stress aggravate them. He has felt increasingly embarrassed by his symptoms in school, and his grades have been dropping from average levels. He has met all his developmental milestones. Vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows intact higher mental functioning and thought processes. Excessive blinking, grunting, and jerking of the shoulders and neck occur while at rest. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is most likely to develop in this patient?

choices.text: Defiant and hostile behavior toward teachers and parents
Feelings of persistent sadness and loss of interest

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Excessive impulsivity, as well as hyperactivity and inattention with impairment of social, occupational, or academic performance are the core features of attention deficit hyperactive disorder (ADHD). About 60% of patients with Tourette syndrome develop concomitant ADHD, making it the most common comorbidity. Obsessive-compulsive disorders (OCD) are also common in patients with Tourette syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Defiant and hostile behavior toward teachers and parents is a classic feature of oppositional defiant disorders. Behavioral problems must persist over a period of ≥ 6 months to make the diagnosis. This patient most likely has Tourette syndrome, which is associated with numerous neuropsychiatric conditions, including oppositional defiant disorders and conduct disorders (15% of cases). However, another childhood neuropsychiatric condition is much more common, occurring in 60% of patients with Tourette syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Dyscalculia is a specific learning disorder that is characterized by problems processing numerical information, learning arithmetic facts, and performing accurate or fluent calculations. Learning disorders may occur in isolation or in association with other neuropsychiatric disorders. Although learning disabilities occur in more than 20% of patients with Tourette syndrome, they are generally associated with concomitant ADHD rather than the tics themselves.

D) INCORRECT:

This boy most likely has Tourette syndrome, which has a high incidence of psychiatric comorbidities. Patients often express shame and anxiety regarding their tics. It is not, however, associated with an increased risk for major depression disorder (MDD).

E) INCORRECT:

Chorea and hyperreflexia are features of Huntington disease (HD). This neurodegenerative condition is an important differential diagnosis of Tourette syndrome since it is also a movement disorder characterized by involuntary and irregular movements of the limbs, neck, head, and/or face. Chorea movements are generally unpredictable and arrhythmic or nonrepetitive, while tic movements due to Tourette syndrome are generally repeated and stereotypical. Furthermore, HD is an autosomal-dominant inherited disease that typically manifests at the age of 40 years. Childhood onset is rare and this patient does not have a family history of HD.

F) INCORRECT:

Recurrent episodes of intense fear, accompanied by vegetative symptoms (sweating, nausea, difficulty breathing, tachycardia) are characteristic for panic attacks. Although patients with Tourette syndrome may develop anxiety disorders such as panic attacks, another childhood neuropsychiatric condition is much more common, occurring in 60% of patients with Tourette syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of involuntary blinking, shrugging, and grunting in combination with a normal physical examination indicates Tourette syndrome, which has a high incidence of comorbidities.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of repetitive involuntary movements, including neck twisting, grimacing, grunting, and blinking, for the past 18 months. Her father reports that her symptoms seem to improve with concentration and worsen when she is tired. During the past 3 months, her symptoms have become so severe that she has missed many school days. She also has too much anxiety about her involuntary movements to see her friends and prefers staying home in her room. Her birth and development until 18 months ago were normal. The father has bipolar disorder. Vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows intact higher mental function and thought processes. Neurologic examination shows multiple motor and vocal tics. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Buspirone is an anxiolytic indicated for the treatment of anxiety disorders (e.g., generalized anxiety disorder, social phobia), depression, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), and symptoms of irritability and aggression. It is not a first-line treatment for tics or Tourette syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Alprazolam is a benzodiazepine used primarily to treat generalized anxiety disorder, panic disorder, night terrors, insomnia and alcohol withdrawal syndrome. It is not recommended for the treatment of Tourette syndrome and may also have side effects that aggravate its symptoms, including agitation, hyperactivity, twitches, and tremors.

C) CORRECT:

Guanfacine and clonidine are alpha-2 adrenergic agonists commonly used for managing tics (e.g., in Tourette syndrome) in children and adolescents, especially in those with comorbid ADHD or anxiety. Alpha-2 adrenergic agonists have a more favorable side effect profile than dopamine receptor antagonists like haloperidol and aripiprazole. Additional treatment options include topiramate and vesicular monoamine transporter type 2 inhibitors such as tetrabenazine, but there is limited evidence to support their use. Comprehensive behavioral intervention for tics (CBIT) is recommended in all patients with functional impairment, and pharmacotherapy is warranted when tics significantly interfere with daily functioning or if CBIT alone is ineffective.

D) INCORRECT:

Fluoxetine is an SSRI used to treat depression, anxiety disorders, obsessive-compulsive disorders, and somatic symptom disorder. While Tourette syndrome may be associated with anxiety disorders and obsessive-compulsive disorders and therefore may show some improvement with fluoxetine treatment, it is not recommended as a first-line treatment for the underlying condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Chlorpromazine is a low-potency antipsychotic that is primarily indicated for schizophrenia, the manic phase of bipolar disorder, and short-term treatment of anxiety (e.g., prior to surgery). While some antipsychotics might be used to treat Tourette syndrome, chlorpromazine is not recommended.
questions.hint: This patient's involuntary vocal and motor tics indicate Tourette syndrome.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because he has been making unusual movements for several years. Recently, he started blinking more frequently for no apparent reason. In the past, he would repeatedly twist his neck, often for several minutes at a time. He has also been copying gestures and sounds that others do since 6 years of age. She reports that the movements worsen when he is tired. When asked about the blinking, he says, “Sometimes I suddenly feel like I must blink and, when I do, I feel much better.” He does not take any medications and has met all developmental milestones. He is at the 80th percentile for height and weight. On physical examination, the boy continues to blink excessively. The conjunctiva is clear and pupils are equal and reactive to light. When the physician asks the boy to keep his eyes open, the blinking subsides. During the examination, the boy repeats some of the words of the physician at increasing speed, but he is otherwise alert and oriented. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Autism spectrum disorders (ASD) typically manifest at the age of 2–3 years (more often in boys) with persistent impairment in communication and social interactions (inability to form relationships, reduced empathy, difficulties in adjusting behavior to social situations, poor eye contact) as well as restricted, stereotyped interests, activities, and behavior (e.g., hand clapping, lining up toys, excessive touching). None of these symptoms are present in this patient. In addition, ASD would not explain this patient's echopraxia, torticollis, or repetitive, involuntary blinking.

B) INCORRECT:

Tardive dyskinesia manifests with irregular, involuntary movements of the tongue, lips, face, extremities, or trunk. While it may be associated with blinking and torticollis, which are present in this patient, tardive dyskinesia would not explain this patient's echolalia and echopraxia. Moreover, tardive dyskinesia occurs in patients taking antidopaminergic agents over months to years; this patient does not take any medications.

C) INCORRECT:

Sporadic transient tic disorder is diagnosed in children (< 18 years of age) based on the presence of motor and/or vocal tics that occur for a period of less than 1 year and resolve spontaneously. Because this patient's symptoms have lasted at least 2 years and have not resolved, they are more consistent with another diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Persistent tic disorder is diagnosed in children (< 18 years of age) based on motor or vocal tics that persist for > 1 year, which is the case here. However, patients with persistent tic disorder have either motor or vocal tics, but not both simultaneously.

E) INCORRECT:

Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is diagnosed in children (< 13 years old) based on a pattern of inattention (e.g., easily distracted, unable to complete work) and/or hyperactivity (e.g., impulsive behavior, excessive talking) that lasts for ≥ 6 months, neither of which is seen in this patient. While ADHD also would not explain this patient's vocal or motor tics, it is a common comorbidity associated with this patient's diagnosis.

F) CORRECT:

Tourette syndrome (TS) is diagnosed in children (< 18 years old) based on the presence of motor tics (e.g., facial grimacing, blinking, torticollis, echopraxia, shoulder shrugging) and vocal tics (e.g., throat clearing, grunting, echolalia, lip-smacking) lasting > 1 year. TS characteristically has a waxing and waning nature, with exacerbation of symptoms occurring during times of stress or fatigue. Tics are commonly preceded by an urge or sensation that is relieved by the tic itself and are often suppressible. Management includes counseling for the patient and caregivers and behavioral therapy, including Comprehensive Behavioral Intervention for Tics (CBIT) and habit reversal training. Pharmacotherapy is indicated in severe or refractory cases and includes alpha-adrenergic agonists (e.g., guanfacine, clonidine), first-generation neuroleptics (e.g., haloperidol, fluphenazine), second-generation neuroleptics (e.g., risperidone), and dopamine depleters (e.g., tetrabenazine). Deep brain stimulation (DBS) is an alternative therapy reserved for patients with severe, distressing tics refractory to behavioral therapy and pharmacotherapy.
questions.hint: This patient's persistent involuntary repetition of others' speech (echolalia) and actions (echopraxia), neck twisting (i.e., torticollis), and repetitive, involuntary, but temporarily suppressible blinking meet the criteria for a diagnosis that is also associated with obsessive-compulsive disorder.

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dopamine-blocking agents such as risperidone can be used to treat severe symptoms that cause functional impairment in tic disorders. However, before any form of treatment can be initiated, this adult patient who presents with a new-onset tic disorder needs to be evaluated for underlying conditions that can cause secondary tics.

B) CORRECT:

Adult-onset tics can be classified as either primary (idiopathic) or secondary to an underlying medical condition or substance use. Primary tics in adults are very rare, and a detailed history often reveals that symptoms are the recurrence of childhood tics. MRI of the brain is indicated in all adults who present with a new onset tic to exclude an underlying secondary cause of tics (e.g., brain lesions involving the basal ganglia, encephalitis).

Additionally, a thorough workup typically includes an evaluation for psychiatric comorbidities, a detailed history of substance use (e.g., cocaine), and targeted testing to exclude other disorders that can cause tics (e.g., copper metabolism studies for Wilson disease, genetic testing for Huntington disease).

C) INCORRECT:

A lumbar puncture can be used to assess the cerebrospinal fluid for conditions that can cause tics, including CNS infections (e.g., meningitis) and paraneoplastic syndromes (e.g., paraneoplastic encephalomyelitis due to small cell lung cancer). This patient has no signs of such a condition (e.g., nuchal rigidity and fever in meningitis, weight loss in paraneoplasia), and other, less invasive diagnostic steps are indicated first.

D) INCORRECT:

Propranolol is used in the treatment of essential tremor, which can affect the hands and/or voice. Symptoms of essential tremor are classically bilateral and worsen with sustained voluntary movement, making this diagnosis unlikely in this patient. Tic disorder, which this patient has, is not typically treated with propranolol.

E) INCORRECT:

Reassurance is appropriate for adult-onset tic disorder only after the exclusion of any underlying medical causes and if the tics do not impair the patient's daily functioning.
questions.hint: This patient presents with premonitory urges followed by brief episodes of involuntary, repetitive muscle movements that can be consciously suppressed. This combination of findings suggests a tic disorder.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his father because of excessive blinking and jumping and sudden, uncontrollable twisting of his body for the past 13 months. His symptoms worsen when he is tired or stressed. His teacher reports that he frequently uses obscene language in class and gets into fights with his friends because he insults their physical appearance. Growth and development are appropriate for age. His only medications are acetaminophen and metoclopramide, which he takes occasionally for fever or nausea. Vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows no abnormalities. During the examination, he says the physician is “stupid and ugly.” The patient frequently jumps and twists his body from side to side on examination. Excessive blinking occurs while at rest. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely clinical course of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Resolution of motor tics with continued vocal tics
Recurrence after initial resolution of symptoms
Complete resolution of symptoms after discontinuation of medication

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In Tourette syndrome, either motor or vocal tics can predominate, and tics may vary in anatomical location, frequency, number, complexity, type, and/or severity over time. However, resolution of motor tics with no improvement in vocal tics is not a typical pattern in Tourette syndrome.

B) CORRECT:

Tourette syndrome manifests before 18 years of age, typically occurring between 4–6 years. The severity of tics usually peaks between 10–12 years of age. This condition typically improves during adolescence, and most affected individuals experience no tics or only mild tics by early adulthood.

Treatment consists of nonpharmacological interventions, such as comprehensive behavioral intervention for tics (CBIT) and habit reversal training. Pharmacotherapy with antidopaminergic drugs, alpha-adrenergic drugs, or neuroleptics is indicated if behavioral interventions are unsuccessful.

C) INCORRECT:

Although tic disorders can resolve in puberty and recur in adulthood (adult-onset tics), this is not the most likely course of Tourette syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Gradual worsening of symptoms over time is typically seen in Huntington disease, which manifests with sudden, involuntary movements of the limbs, neck, head, and face. Common features of Huntington disease such as sensory deficits (e.g., clumsiness), dementia, and/or autonomic symptoms (e.g., hyperhidrosis, urinary incontinence) are not seen here. Additionally, Huntington disease occurs during adulthood (20–50 years of age) rather than childhood. Although symptoms of Tourette syndrome may worsen over time, another clinical course is more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Tardive dyskinesia due to dopamine antagonists (e.g., metoclopramide) can completely resolve with discontinuation. Although tardive dyskinesia can manifest with involuntary movements of the mouth, tongue, face, and limbs, vocal tics (e.g., coprolalia) are not expected.
questions.hint: Multiple motor tics (jumping, twisting the body, blinking) along with a vocal tic (coprolalia) lasting for > 1 year in a child suggest Tourette syndrome.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old girl presents to an outpatient clinic for her annual physical. Her parents note that she grunts, blinks her eyes, and clears her throat many times a day, almost every day. During the past few years, she has had some months where the behaviors were very mild and others where they were more frequent. The patient has no known medical conditions and takes no medications. Her parents report that she does well in school and has a good number of friends.
On physical examination, she has a normal nonfocal neurologic examination but does have frequent eye blinking and occasional throat clearing and head jerking.
Which one of the following management strategies is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antipsychotic medications, such as haloperidol and pimozide, can be very effective at suppressing tics, but they are not considered first-line therapy because of their adverse effects.

B) INCORRECT:

For some children, the tics affect daily function, cause social isolation, and even lead to self-injury. In these cases, behavioral or pharmacologic therapy is often indicated to suppress the tics. Cognitive behavioral therapy, including habit-reversal training, and biofeedback have proven useful for reducing the number and severity of tics. With these techniques, patients are trained to recognize their tics and channel them into behaviors that are incompatible with their tics or are at least less noticeable.

C) CORRECT:

The presence of motor and vocal tics for more than one year is consistent with Tourette syndrome. Motor tics can include twitching, eye blinking, facial grimacing, and head jerking, although they can also be more purposeful-looking movements such as tapping or touching. Vocal tics can include throat clearing, sniffing, and coughing, as well as full or partial words.

The severity of the tics associated with Tourette syndrome can vary greatly and will determine management. For most children, the tics are mild and nondebilitating (as in this case), and education with supportive counseling is sufficient. For some children, though, the tics affect daily function, cause social isolation, and even lead to self-injury. In these cases, behavioral or pharmacologic therapy is often indicated to suppress the tics.

If pharmacologic therapy is warranted, alpha-2-adrenergic agonists (such as guanfacine and clonidine) are tried first, as they have a limited side effect profile. Botulinum toxin injections may be considered in patients with a single muscle motor tic that is painful or spastic.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial management for a child with Tourette syndrome whose tics are mild and not disabling is education and supportive counseling.

D) INCORRECT:

Speech therapy has not been shown to improve symptoms in children with Tourette syndrome, although this strategy could be helpful if the child has a known concurrent speech.

E) INCORRECT:

Intensive physical therapy has not been shown to improve symptoms in children with Tourette syndrome, although this strategy could be helpful if the child has a known motor delay.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to frequent, brief episodes of rapid eye blinking over the past two months. Each episode lasts less than a second and occurs multiple times per day, regardless of activity. He denies discomfort, does not lose consciousness, and can temporarily suppress the episodes when asked. His growth and development are appropriate for his age. General examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Provisional tic disorder involves motor and/or vocal tics present for at least one month but less than one year. The rapid eye blinking in this child is a simple motor tic, characterized by its brief, sudden, repetitive nature and ability to be voluntarily suppressed. Tics are nonrhythmic and not associated with impaired awareness, distinguishing them from epileptic events. The child's normal development and absence of neurological deficits align with the benign nature of tic disorders in children.

Key learning point: Frequent, brief episodes of rapid eye blinking in a child, without associated symptoms of discomfort or loss of awareness, are suggestive of a tic disorder.

B) INCORRECT:

Absence epilepsy presents with episodes of impaired consciousness or brief lapses in awareness, typically lasting several seconds and not under voluntary control. The child's episodes are brief, suppressible, and lack any alteration in consciousness, which is inconsistent with absence epilepsy.

C) INCORRECT:

Complex partial seizures, or focal impaired awareness seizures, involve altered consciousness, automatisms, and impaired responsiveness. The child's brief, suppressible eye blinking episodes without loss of consciousness or postictal confusion do not align with the typical features of complex partial seizures.

D) INCORRECT:

Blepharospasm is a focal dystonia with sustained, involuntary contractions of the orbicularis oculi muscles, leading to prolonged eye closure. It is more common in middle-aged individuals and is not suppressible, unlike the brief, suppressible episodes seen in this child.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents for “jerking movements” of the face and shoulders for the past month. Vital signs and neurologic examination are normal. Which of the following features of his jerking movements would suggest a benign tic disorder rather than another movement disorder?

choices.text: Repetitive, stereotyped movements preceded by a premonitory sensation and temporarily suppressible with effort
Brief, irregular movements that shift unpredictably between muscle groups and are not preceded by any sensation
Sustained contractions or twisting postures that briefly interrupt voluntary motion and are not suppressible
Variable, distractible movements that change with attention and lack a consistent pattern or premonitory urge
Sudden, shock-like jerks of a single muscle group without pattern or premonitory sensation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct — These are the hallmark features of a tic disorder. Tics are brief, repetitive, and patterned, often preceded by an internal urge that is relieved by performing the movement. They can be voluntarily suppressed for short periods, distinguishing them from chorea (irregular), myoclonus (nonsuppressible jerks), or seizures (involuntary events with altered awareness).

B) INCORRECT:

These movements describe chorea, which is characterized by random, nonpatterned motions that migrate between muscle groups. Unlike tics, choreiform movements lack a premonitory urge and are not voluntarily suppressible.

C) INCORRECT:

This pattern describes dystonia, which produces sustained, twisting, or postural movements rather than brief, phasic tics. Dystonic movements lack premonitory sensation and are usually provoked by specific voluntary actions, not anxiety or stress.

D) INCORRECT:

This description fits a psychogenic (functional) movement disorder, in which movements are inconsistent, suggestible, and influenced by distraction. Unlike true tics, functional movements lack a stereotyped pattern or premonitory sensation, and suppressibility is inconsistent.

E) INCORRECT:

These movements correspond to myoclonus, which may be physiologic or pathologic (e.g., metabolic or epileptic). Myoclonus is non-suppressible and non-stereotyped, unlike the patterned, suppressible movements of tics.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for sudden onset of facial grimacing, sniffing, and shoulder jerking that began one week ago. His parents report associated irritability, emotional lability, and obsessive handwashing behaviors. Three weeks earlier, he was treated for pharyngitis. He has no history of neurologic disease, trauma, or medication exposure. Vital signs are normal. Neurologic examination reveals intermittent motor tics and vocal sniffing but no weakness, tremor, or ataxia. Which of the following is the most appropriate management approach in the emergency department?

choices.text: Initiate haloperidol and refer to outpatient psychiatry
Reassure the family that the tics are transient and self-limited
Obtain basic laboratory studies and urgently refer to neurology
Admit for continuous EEG monitoring to exclude seizure activity
Initiate selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor therapy and arrange outpatient psychiatry follow-up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pharmacologic suppression of tics should be avoided until secondary causes are excluded. In PANDAS and similar postinfectious disorders, dopamine blockade may obscure the diagnostic picture and carries unnecessary risk.

B) INCORRECT:

While transient tics are common, this child’s acute onset following streptococcal infection and new obsessive-compulsive behaviors suggest a secondary process rather than a benign provisional tic disorder. Reassurance alone would miss a potentially treatable neuropsychiatric syndrome.

C) CORRECT:

Correct — The abrupt appearance of motor and vocal tics with new-onset obsessive-compulsive behaviors after a recent streptococcal infection is concerning for Pediatric Autoimmune Neuropsychiatric Disorders Associated with Streptococcal infection (PANDAS). ED care includes symptomatic management, baseline labs (CBC, metabolic panel, possibly ASO titer), and expedited neurology/psychiatry referral. Routine reassurance or antipsychotic therapy is inappropriate at this stage.

D) INCORRECT:

The history and examination do not suggest epilepsy; EEG monitoring is unnecessary.

E) INCORRECT:

Although this child exhibits obsessive-compulsive behaviors, the abrupt onset following streptococcal infection suggests a secondary autoimmune process (PANDAS) rather than primary OCD. SSRIs are used for chronic, idiopathic OCD, but initiation is not appropriate in the ED and should not precede neurologic evaluation for a possible postinfectious etiology. Early specialty referral is the correct next step.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the outpatient clinic by his mother because of involuntary grimacing and throat clearing for the past 13 months. He also frequently experiences episodes of sudden, brief shoulder jerks several times per day. These movements increase when he is anxious and are sometimes accompanied by vocal outbursts, such as grunting. He is performing well academically but has become self-conscious around classmates. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable. His maternal uncle has attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. On physical examination, the patient repeatedly clears his throat, grimaces, and shrugs his shoulders. The rest of the examination shows no abnormalities. Brain MRI shows reduced caudate nuclei volume. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Botulinum toxin injections partially paralyze the muscles and may be used for controlling focal motor tics or vocal tics in adults and adolescents. This patient presents with generalized motor tics for which another initial therapy is more appropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

Methylphenidate is used to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, which is often concurrent with Tourette syndrome. However, methylphenidate does not treat tics and occasionally worsens them. A different therapy that treats tics is indicated in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Deep brain stimulation is reserved for severe, refractory Tourette syndrome that has not responded to other treatment modalities and is causing significant functional impairment. This approach is not appropriate as initial therapy, especially in children, because it is invasive, and there is limited long-term data on its safety and efficacy in pediatric populations.

D) CORRECT:

Comprehensive behavioral intervention for tics (CBIT) that includes habit reversal therapy is the first-line treatment for children with Tourette syndrome. This approach involves increasing the patient's awareness of premonitory urges and training them to perform voluntary, competing responses when they feel tics coming on. Early behavioral intervention can reduce tic frequency and social consequences, and is preferred due to its safety and efficacy. Pharmacotherapy (e.g., guanfacine, haloperidol, tetrabenazine) is reserved for severe tics that cause functional impairment and/or when behavioral interventions fail.

Tourette syndrome is characterized by both motor and vocal tics persisting for over a year, often exacerbated by stress or anxiety. MRI typically shows reduced caudate nucleus volume, reflecting dysfunction in cortico-striatal-thalamo-cortical circuits.

E) INCORRECT:

Haloperidol may be used in the treatment of Tourette syndrome, but it is not the first-line therapy because of the risk of extrapyramidal adverse effects, sedation, and cognitive dulling. Pharmacotherapy is reserved for patients with severe tics that cause functional impairment and/or those who do not respond to initial therapy. This patient has mild-to-moderate symptoms and preserved functioning, so another initial therapy is more appropriate.
questions.hint: This patient presents with involuntary vocal and motor tics and a normal physical examination. In conjunction with the MRI findings, these features suggest Tourette syndrome.
